head.title: Finding Deals, Small Businesses Buy More Online

hedline.hl1: Finding Deals, Small Businesses Buy More Online

abstract.p: Survey by Access Markets International Partners finds that small-business owners are going online in droves looking for deals, particularly on computer equipment, office supplies and travel reservations; graph (M)

block.p: Small-business owners are going online in droves looking for deals, particularly on computer equipment, office supplies and travel reservations, according to a survey planned for release today by Access Markets International Partners, a market research firm in New York.

The trend was so strong that small businesses spent more online last year than consumers did, the survey showed. It said small businesses in the United States spent $25 billion online in 1999, which was up from only $2 billion in 1998 and topped the $20 billion spent by consumers.

Small-business owners are going online in droves looking for deals, particularly on computer equipment, office supplies and travel reservations, according to a survey planned for release today by Access Markets International Partners, a market research firm in New York.

The trend was so strong that small businesses spent more online last year than consumers did, the survey showed. It said small businesses in the United States spent $25 billion online in 1999, which was up from only $2 billion in 1998 and topped the $20 billion spent by consumers.
Small businesses are expected to spend $118 billion online in 2001, according to Andy Bose, president and chief executive of Access Markets, which co-sponsored the survey with Inc. magazine.

Small business customers have also learned there is strength in numbers: 1.3 million of them are interested in using the Internet to pool their purchasing with their peers to obtain better prices online.

The findings are good news for Web companies like Demandline.com, based in San Mateo, Calif. Demandline is one of a crop of services that creates buying groups of small business customers, and uses a reverse-auction format to let the customer group name the prices they are willing to pay for goods and services. The survey indicated that small businesses are comfortable with auction sites: nearly one million of them plan to participate in online auctions this year.

But the survey also had some bad news for e-commerce. While many are comfortable shopping online, 6 of 10 small businesses owners said they they were not interested in selling there and that they were overwhelmed by the technical challenges.
But then, some 600,000 small businesses have already made the jump to online sales. ''There's a lot of opportunity,'' Mr. Bose said, ''but also a lot of apprehension.''
